I also learned from my Dark Souls 1 experience that a trend in the series is bosses with attacks that will straight up miss if you're right next to them; DS3 mostly put a stop to this but they're back in full force in Elden Ring and you need to take advantage of this

I beat the bloodletting beast on the first try because I stayed right next to it and it turns out you can use the beast's own body as cover from the rain attack and when you're close it won't do its most dangerous move, when I needed to heal I'd dodge something then do it

Radahn, Demon of Hatred, the Bloodletting Beast, the thing all these have in common is that the safest place to be is usually right next to them, and trying to run away to heal will get you hit; you earn a heal by either finding a safe zone where an attack won't hit, or dodging

I've noticed a trend in the soulsborne bosses (not ones that are broken like bed of chaos or ancient dragon) that everyone hates and a repeated factor is "you can't run away to heal" and I'm starting to notice I never find these bosses as bad as everyone else

6. The alternative to the honor rule is if the opponent clearly wants nothing but an unfair win. Are they clearly sitting around in groups of 3 waiting for invaders? Has your invader gone and try to lure you into a group of tough enemies? Then do whatever cheap shit you want.

5. Honor exists even if your opponent has summoned help. You may be at a disadvantage but you still should not attack the opponent when they're engaged in PVE against tough enemies. Your goal when invading or being invaded should never be to get an unfair win.
4. If you want to really beat up invaders, find a large area with no enemies and use the mad tongue, and don't summon. A fair fight is all most invaders really want.

3. If you just summon multiple players and sit around waiting to gank invaders, you aren't fighting some righteous cause against bullies, you're an asshole. Invaders are the underdogs and, from my experience with the mad tongue, are often surprisingly honorable.
2. Once PVP begins it is common courtesy to let both players do their gesture, chug their physicks, and apply buffs. Don't attack during this time or you're a dick.

PVP etiquette in Elden Ring
1. If you invade and the opponent runs away, casually follow them but don't attack. They are trying to get to a grace point so they can recover their souls if you kill them. Don't engage until they're ready especially if their co op partner dies.

@alcratz by "every attack is avoidable" I exclude his spread shot arrows but those have hit me like 40 times and only killed me once so they're whatever.

@alcratz From my time learning the attack telegraphs, they actually all seem really good. He has a lot of things he does to make absolutely sure you know he's going to attack. There are much worse bosses in the series, he's just really fucking frustrating

@alcratz like I said, it's doable, the fight isn't broken, and every single attack the boss has is completely avoidable. In terms of being "bullshit" or "unfair" nothing in the fight is particularly bad aside from the frustration increasing elements making the fight painful. So it's both

If you're trying to DPS race the fight to avoid his most annoying phase keeping the NPCs alive is really important, since you want to have a distraction up to the end so you can get more hits off and kill him

and assuming you summon there's also luck based elements, since how long the NPC summons will live is dependent on the moves Radahn chooses to do and how many NPCs he manages to hit during it; god help you if he goes all out on his 360 spinning bullshit attack

classic "frustration boosting elements" include:
1. long and unskippable or difficult to speed up segments before the fight
2. Moves that instantly kill you even if you're well equipped
3. Saving the most difficult to dodge moves for the very end (not just half health)

I've seen a lot of comparisons of Radahn to the bed of chaos, and I think they're bullshit for different reasons. Bed of chaos is just broken, but Radahn is bullshit because he contains what I like to call "frustration boosting elements"

the idea also includes self sacrificing being a good thing if the other person gains more than you lose; I consider myself very well off compared to most people in service industries so I feel good about tipping generously as they may get more out of that money than I would
this kind of conundrum is part of what moved me to become a utilitarian where my own happiness is factored into moral decisions as long as it is balanced with the happiness of others

an example of being overly self sacrificing is the idea of "I don't want to enter the job market because me getting a job means someone else doesn't get that job" and this is the kind of problem that forced me to rethink how I approach the idea of selflessness
Not to say I haven't had my moments of selfishness because trust me I have as well, usually when the amount I want something blinds my judgement (which does not happen often but does happen)

number 1 I've had to learn because my tendency is towards selflessness to the point where sometimes, I'm self sacrificing in a way that is disproportionate to what others gain from it, and I don't believe that's actually a morally good thing.

2. Putting the happiness of loved ones and people you care about disproportionately above the happiness of strangers is a form of selfishness; obviously you will care more about loved ones but you shouldn't make the world overall worse in order for your loved ones to gain

Two aspects of morality I believe in that I don't think are talked about much
1. You have a moral imperative not to put others disproportionately above yourself the same way you have one to not put yourself above others; selflessness to the point of misery isn't healthy

@MANMADEOFGOLD after doing a single full step for each camera, it takes the max distance that each camera has stepped and applies it to the other cameras; this "syncing" not only speeds us towards the early exit, but also means individual cameras will not get stuck on missing data

@MANMADEOFGOLD this optimization means that for the vast majority of pixel chunks it does not run the full loop which means the quality can be increased to significant levels with almost no effect on performance

@MANMADEOFGOLD this is combined with two early outs; if the shader accelerates past the object and escapes the bounds of the object, it early exits the loop; conversely, if all the mip levels for the cameras reach the min mip level, that's considered a full detail collision and we early exit

@MANMADEOFGOLD through this method the shader continually raises the step size, "speeding up" when there's no collisions, and when it's approaching detail, it slows down and fine tunes so it makes sure it will not miss anything

@MANMADEOFGOLD 2. each mip map contains the info for both that mip and for a lower LOD level in 2 color channels, so that with one sample you can step 2 steps forward, 1 step forward, or not at all based on whether there's a collision, and raise or lower the step size accordingly

@MANMADEOFGOLD The way the custom mipmapping works is two fold:
1. mips are the max of all the depth values of the higher mip, instead of an average, so that when sampling a mip, the shader knows the highest value in the depth map on that segment so that it won't miss a single pixel

@MANMADEOFGOLD The purpose of the custom mipmapping is actually pretty interesting; the original purpose was to make sure that it couldn't miss geometry (stepping through depth textures with a POM like technique tends to do that) but in the end it ended up significantly speeding up the shader.

@MANMADEOFGOLD I stand corrected, this shader is actually incredibly useful for rendering a ton of high poly objects.
The camera count on these imposters are pretty low. Right now you get pretty good quality on this shoe out of just 6 source images.

@MANMADEOFGOLD It was interesting but I don't think it's performant enough or high quality enough to have a viable use case. It was just an experiment to challenge myself with trying to render a 3D object whose data was not polygons or voxels.

@MANMADEOFGOLD I'll try to explain though, basically there's a loop that's pixel crawling across a bunch of render textures with custom mip maps, and climbing up and down mip maps based on collision or no collision, and syncing each other up as they move forward.

@MANMADEOFGOLD Unfortunately the blog I'm going to make a post about it on is linked to my real name and only meant to be seen by potential employers. There's too much weird shit going on in this shader to explain in a twitter thread.

The capsule problem can by fixed by sweeping your downwards movement and only counting collisions above a certain distance to get behavior similar to that of a cylinder. With physics based characters the friction problem can be a bit harder to fix but it's still important.
Both capsule collision and friction can stop this from working so if you have a physics based character controller you want to account for both of these.

One thing you should always test for your character controller is, if I have a wall that's exactly high enough for me to theoretically jump on top of, and I go right up against it and jump while holding towards it, can I land on it?

I feel like the 2 biggest mistakes budding developers make with character physics are:
1. capsule collision for the bottom of a character (especially a problem with certain engines)
2. friction shortening the jump height when jumping up against a wall

Imagine using Boneworks' climbing mechanics to scale as Shadow of the Colossus scale boss while it's moving around. Just imagine that. There's so much possible with this type of game with an AAA budget instead of HL Alyx that uses VR very conservatively at the expense of depth.

Tip for playing boneworks to prevent injury and soreness:
1. Make big sweeping medium-speed movements instead of fast movements

Another one is shadow acne (striped shadows when an object is at a certain angle) which is expensive to mitigate and damn near impossible to fully remove in all situations. I'm excited for the death of shadow acne as well with raytraced shadows.

Traditional shadow mapping is infamous for having a lot of problems one of which is that shadows that soften based on distance like real shadows are impossible to do accurately due to information lost by the process, which is one thing I'm excited to see raytracing fix
As a graphics programmer I am way more excited for raytraced shadows being the death of traditional shadow mapping than I am about raytraced reflections

In HL Alyx it feels like the only choice you get to make is "what kind of gun will I use on enemies" which is a choice that quickly gets taken away from you when you run out of ammo for the gun you prefer to use

For how jank and lacking general polish and accessibility Boneworks is compared to HL Alyx, Boneworks NAILS player expression with its non-linear puzzle design and multiple approaches to combat, in a way that makes HL Alyx feel primitive by comparison.

They had a crowbar in the game to start with but didn't want you swinging something and smacking a dog/kid/grandma/etc. The proper solution was to implement a melee weapon like a taser that you don't have to swing, not remove melee from the game entirely.

The lack of a melee option in HL Alyx is one of its biggest problems compared to other shooters; your only ways of doing damage is grenades (if you have them) or shooting. This severely limits gameplay depth and player expression.

What used to be limited to certain genres like Deus Ex is now standard almost across all action / action adventure type games, but in HL Alyx it feels like 99% of the time when I do something "smart" it's something the devs works real hard to direct me to do it

I feel like in the modern day, games have evolved a lot to allow for more depth and player expression and "play how you want" mentality, giving you a lot of ways to approach situations and solve problems. And I feel like HL:Alyx missed this evolution.

This is a situation where many games will just kill you (dark souls / bloodborne), some games will just softlock you (deathloop) and some games will make you slide across the map at huge distances (grand theft auto 5). I have to praise the thoughtfulness of the design here.

Your character will either jump out of the buggy geometry back onto the navmesh, or if the spot is too far the screen will fade to black and your character will reappear back on safe ground. Even among the most polished games I've played I've never seen jank resistance like this.

Ghost of Tsushima's jank resistance mechanics are really something special. I have tried to get several stupid and funny things to happen in the places where you can get stuck in geometry (which exist in every open world game) and the game is ludicrously good at handling it.

If it was framed as "tell us about your interests VOLUNTARILY and we will be more likely to show you ads you're interested in" wouldn't everyone just be way happier?

Any venture capitalists, this idea's free. People don't want to consent to selling all sorts of random private data to advertisers, but most of these people would be HAPPY to just TELL you that they like cheesesteak or whatever the fuck.

Like how have none of these big data harvesting companies thought of the simple fucking solution of ASKING for your interests instead of stealing a bunch of fucking data from your phones and tracking your location and shit trying to figure them out

Like imagine you have an account to some centralized system and you just tell it all your fucking interests down to the specifics, and while you're logged in it just makes all the ads on the internet match your interests

What if instead of all this dystopian bullshit where you are getting all kinds of data stolen from your phones and tracked cookies and shit, have any of these marketing companies thought to open a website and just have you TELL them what your fucking interests are?

Just for fun I scrolled down on twitter until I got an ad that even remotely matches my interests. I scrolled over 8 ads before it advertised me a video game. What the fuck? Video games are like one of my 3 or 4 interests. How are my twitter ads not like, all video games?

I feel like the first thing ads can do is stop showing me the same goddamn ad over and over and over. Twitch has a serious problem with this. If your video game commercial didn't capture my interest the first time why the fuck would it the next 10 times

It really feels like the entire internet and all of tech venture capitalism is living in this bubble of the myth of targeted advertising and some day they're going to finally realize that it's all a sham

If people were getting ads for things they actually wanted to buy, why would people hate ads so fucking much? Why would people consider them such an annoyance to the point where more and more people are using adblock?

Doesn't it feel like this entire system of violating everyone's privacy and tracking everyone's position and shit is based on some myth that marketing and data companies think is happening, that people are getting targeted ads that actually work, but it's all bullshit?

Imagine if you were getting ads for cool new indie games you didn't know about that are totally your thing. Imagine if you were getting ads for local restaurants that have your favorite type of food. I'd turn off adblock everywhere for ads like that.

But instead I get that wendy's ad because everyone's getting that wendy's ad, and when it comes to more obscure things I never get shown anything that piques my interest because targeted advertising is just bad

The best ad I've gotten in the last couple years is for the bacon pub cheeseburger at wendy's (why did they discontinue it?) which I've ordered like 25 times. If my privacy was being violated to show me ads like that, which I would actually benefit from, I'd be a lot less pissy

The best case for an ad on the side of both the company and the consumer is the ad showing the consumer something they didn't know they wanted. Instead what they do is figure out I'm interested in video games and show me a video game themed taco bell commercial

We have to deal with our data being harvested and abused and yet the reason that it's being done is to show us targeted ads. I feel like people would be less upset about the data harvesting if targeted ads worked but let's face it they fucking don't

Bloodborne is full of these - the opening area with huge hoards of enemies, the first mandatory boss (gascoigne) who is incredibly difficult, the big open forest easy to get lost in, the nightmare of mensis - all these areas designed to seem hard but be possible to brute force

You can tell the difference between some of the segments like the capra demon and the archers in DS1, which are annoying and easy to get stuck at but not terribly intimidating, and the sections in Bloodborne like the Nightmare of Mensis which are horribly intimidating but doable

especially notable in the later games, like Bloodborne and Dark Souls 3 - these games are full of areas that seem hopelessly difficult but are designed to be not only doable, but doable to the point of being unlikely for players to get stuck unless they are over-intimidated

Fromsoft's games are full of situations that are, on paper, hopelessly against the player's favor, but most of them are subtly designed to prod the player into figuring out the strategy to deal with the "unfair" hard areas

I feel like the ethos of Fromsoft's soulsborne games is to FEEL inaccessible and unfair while secretly being accessible and fair as possible - their popularity triumphed over other "hard" games for this reason, and you can see them reaching this ethos better in later games

for instance Dark Souls follows almost no jrpg story or gameplay tropes but doesn't really follow western ones either, so calling it an action game / action adventure game with RPG elements would be more appropriate

Remember the primary reason to say a game is a specific genre is communication and if you have an RPG where neither term really communicates well what type of game it is (like Undertale or Dark Souls) it's best to not use jRPG or wRPG in the first place

Some genres like "metroidvania" or "soulslike" or "roguelite" are less fuzzy and easier to objectively pin down, but IMO if you want to capture whether a game feels like a "jRPG" or "wRPG" it's easier to say "ok, what games are this game like and which are they considered to be"

Tropes common to either genre are so incredibly numerous that it makes the genre definitions fuzzy and makes it easier to list a few games that a game is more like and see what genre those games are generally agreed to be, than to try to define the genre of a game in a vacuum

being literal about the term "western RPG" or "japanese RPG" does not serve the purpose of genres to group similar games together and Dragon's Dogma, a game that's much more like Fable than Final Fantasy, is a great example

Dragon's Dogma is an RPG made in Japan that heavily, heavily follows western RPG gameplay and story tropes and classifying it as a JRPG puts it in a weird place what that genre classification does not accurately describe what the game is like

you will always find a game that fits most of these definitions but defies one or two, so you have to remember that genres are not always objective and again, the primary purpose of genres are grouping similar games together, not having one single concrete thing that defines it

the way combat works with party mechanics (but not always), the way the game world is laid out (but not always), how quests and sidequests work (not always), how the RPG mechanics work (not always), the story tropes used (not always), etc.

With a genre like "Roguelite" there is a really solid set of essential mechanics that are necessary for it to qualify (randomly generated levels / enemy placements and some type of permadeath) but with JRPG it's more a loose set of gameplay and story tropes

Some genres like "JRPGs" are really fuzzy because many games in that genre deviate from the norm in one way or another but defining it as "every RPG made in Japan" is not helpful because the purpose of genres is to group similar games

Genre arguments get really stupid because I believe the primary purpose of genres is to group similar games together and so when someone tries to pigeonhole every genre out there with one or two specific objective metrics it leads to stupid conclusions

Often that means attacking the same enemy as an AI partner and at higher levels (I'm not there yet but I've done stuff like this) paying attention to the attacks they're doing and using them to fill the "gaps" in your moveset to make the combo tighter

Tales of Arise's combo system, where if you combo elegantly enough you can kill an enemy super early, but when they have more health your combo has to be tighter, means that the skill curve is absolutely massive, as you can figure out more complex tech to finish the combo earlier

Nier Automata's combat is tighter and more mechanically solid, but Tales of Arise has a longer skill curve and is more demanding, and with more complex systems it asks you to understand in order to play it well. Arise wins based on that.
I was only somewhat prepared to even like Tales of Arise, I was not ready for it to yank the title of "best combat in a JRPG" out of the hands of Nier Automata for me

I've played more than my share of games where you are punished for death by a loss of gradually obtained / long term resources. DON'T do this. This not only makes the user terrified to take risks but also can severely fuck over their entire playthrough if they die too much.

A lot of game devs don't seem to understand what makes good punishment for death,
Dark Souls is famous for being punishing but the worst punishment is a loss of quickly obtained short term resources.
You don't want long term punishments because they discourage taking risks.

And if they try to force users to use their transaction app anyways so they can get those analytics, then using technology designed to make transactions decentralized becomes completely pointless

I want to clarify, in terms of analytics, the company (and everyone else) has access to sales data because it's stored on the ledger, but if it's decentralized they lose access to any other analytics, such as searches, declined sales, and anything else a user might do in the app

Any other in game economy, like Valve's famous TF2 hats or Countrstrike skins, it's in the company's best interest to maintain control over its economy as well as the ability to get information from it

The only way it would be desirable is a game like Eve Online where the fluid nature and lack of oversight over the economy is literally one of the biggest major selling point, that would be perfect for the blockchain

All the hype over bitcoin and NFTs as a get rich quick scheme are eclipsing the original purpose of the technology which makes it desirable in certain circumstances and not very desirable in others, if a company wants control over their marketplace it's not desirable

these companies have literally nothing to gain by switching to the blockchain because all it's doing is losing the control you have over and the ability to get analytics from your own microtransaction marketplace, the only reason CEOs show interest is because it's a tech trend

How long until the advisers to the gaming CEOs who are "interested in the blockchain/bitcoin/NFTs" explain to them that the whole purpose of that technology is to decentralize transactions which is the last thing you want to do as a game company

I don't think there's ever going to be another Metroidvania that lets you sequence break as fucking MASSIVELY hard without glitches as Ori and the Will of the Wisps
That game was a fucking anomaly in that regard, it's on par with Super Metroid

@davidscottjaffe Even if you get stuck again, I really want to you to bear with it because as the game goes on the boss fights get increasingly better and better and even if you come away not liking the other parts of the design you should at least stick with it just for the bosses

@davidscottjaffe Also knowledge that you'll need to shoot at most walls, especially when you don't know where to go, will help, and the game eventually gives you an item that shows you all of the walls in the immediate area that can be broken and after that point you won't have to worry about it

@davidscottjaffe Once you get acclimated to the controls (aiming with the left stick while running and shooting up and down, I know this takes some getting used to since it's not typical twin stick controls) the chances you'll get stuck like this will be a lot less.

@davidscottjaffe I actually saw the bug turn around when you entered the room when rewatching your footage. I still think you should give the game another chance even if you think it's bad design. Don't let people tell you "the game's just like that" and let that turn you off from it.
@davidscottjaffe I think you will appreciate the boss fights in Metroid Dread a lot, they excel in both quantity and quality, and I think you would be missing out not to give the game another shot.

@davidscottjaffe That all said even if you disagree with me, I highly suggest giving the game another chance. I similarly quit The Wonderful 101 very early on for a similar reason but after going back to it it was one of my favorite action games. As an action game designer...
@davidscottjaffe except in your case because your habits thus far in the game had you shooting the enemy horizontally so you did not get an extra chance to break the ceiling tiles.

@davidscottjaffe When a player is acclimated to the controls and they get to this part, they naturally will shoot up at the bug and break the ceiling tiles, and if for whatever reason they fail to, while looking around the very limited area they'll come back in and have another chance...

@davidscottjaffe it's not your fault for not acclimating to the aiming system this early in the game especially if you have not played a Metroid game in a long time, but you see the intended player experience and why it works, right?

@davidscottjaffe destructible blocks, since the enemy takes more than 1 shot to kill you'll probably shoot repeatedly and break the ceiling tiles

During your footage you were shooting at the enemy like this, which you were having some difficulty killing it with https://t.co/EI3xMFJJHF
@davidscottjaffe @Philip_Jonas There's an enemy on Samus's side of the ceiling, you're intended to aim up and shoot repeatedly, and the shot that you do after the enemy dies will break the ceiling

@davidscottjaffe It's just because of the structure, metroidvanias are more closed than open world games so you can't just walk straight to your goal, and more open than more linear games so it's easy to get lost. You can't always guarantee no one will get stuck no matter how good the design is.

@davidscottjaffe After that point the game is very effective of nudging you in the right direction despite being open but getting stuck in Metroidvanias is a VERY common experience and sometimes you just have to deal with needing to look something up, or if you're a streamer, have chat tell you
@davidscottjaffe so I went back on the elevator and just shot everything and found the destructible wall pretty fast.

@davidscottjaffe Right now the biggest problematic destructible wall is later in the game but even that is right after an elevator ride during said railroaded linear part of the game, I originally turned around and then realized that the game wouldn't have given me an elevator ride to a dead end

@davidscottjaffe and the first third or so of the game railroads you REALLY hard into always going the intended way as an attempt to make sure you don't get confused on which way to go until you are properly acclimated to the mechanics of the game.

@davidscottjaffe Also yeah getting stuck because Metroid is traditionally full of blocks that are not indicated to be destructible is a completely fair criticism of the series but in my experience Dread generally does a great job at directing you at any non-optional destructible blocks

@davidscottjaffe tldr I'm not going to blame you for that room and most of the twitter responses blaming you don't properly understand the reason you did not have the intended experience, but hopefully you understand why your experience was an outlier and the design isn't bad

@davidscottjaffe And your experience with the room is because of the specific way you defeated that enemy which the game designers didn't forsee but isn't a common approach to the game's combat (seeing as you can aim up with the left stick even when not free aiming)

@davidscottjaffe People are saying there are visual cues and I absolutely agree with you that, in fact, there aren't, and it's not your fault for skipping the tutorial because games should teach through gameplay
But the point of the enemy on that ceiling is to make you shoot the ceiling

@davidscottjaffe Making there be cracks or clear damage in the ceiling would not effectively teach the lesson that some blocks are destructible and said blocks are not always visibly indicative that they're destructible which is the intended lesson of this room
@davidscottjaffe And in cases where they missed the spot on the ceiling, they'd come back into this room and shoot at the enemy again and be more likely to hit it

@davidscottjaffe I don't blame you for this but even for people who have not played a metroid game and skipped the tutorial ("there was an easily skipped tutorial" is not a good design defense) most of them would have aimed up and hit the ceiling, that's why the enemy is there

@davidscottjaffe David I sympathize with you on this but your screenshot is missing an enemy that is on the ceiling when you enter the room; in your footage you jumped and shot the enemy like mega man but if you had pressed the left stick up and shot at it you would have hit the ceiling

Anyone in the public eye will eventually make an embarrassing mistake, especially people who stream and record their footage and post it unedited. Before piling on to make fun of someone who does, please remember that you yourself have almost certainly made similar mistakes (4/?)

In these cases it is important for both the people watching to empathize with the frustration as well as the frustrated person to empathize with the game designers and think about if getting stuck there is a likely outcome for most players before declaring bad game design (3/?)

That said, in cases where good design DOES direct you into performing an action that accidentally teaches you the mechanic (on top of the tutorial) there will always be outliers, people with weird habits that do something that blocks them from figuring it out (2/?)

I want to say, devoid of context, "you missed the tutorial prompt so it's your fault for getting stuck" is not a good defense of a game, they should be designed so that with every tutorial prompt skipped you will eventually be forced to figure out every essential mechanic (1/?)

@TamashiiHiroka Some of them are pretty easy, especially ones I found later on, but yeah lots of them are hard or inconsistent

The only fun glitch they fixed was the exploding skaters being launched so far and tbh I get why they did that because being launched across the map at a million miles an hour is a potential instability and could lead to crashes (which indeed can happen on the art school DLC map)

The ramp launch glitch was found in the demo and they could have fixed it at any time but it allowed you to do so much fun stuff and it would have been a shame if they patched it, and I'm so happy and thankful they didn't

I also have to give the team massive props for not fixing a large host of glitches that they could have been tempted to fix Rockstar style to make the game "more polished" but didn't fix them because they were fun

All of the major bugs exist on the fringe of messing around and you aren't likely to ever get interrupted from the core skateboarding gameplay by a glitch, which for how dynamic the systems are is a goddamn QA miracle.

The reason so many glitches in Skate 3 exist is because 100% of the bug fixing was done on the core gameplay which is rock solid and it took me like 6 months to find anything entertainingly buggy about the game.

the fact that my videos gave people the impression that Skate 3 was unpolished or bad or not tested properly will never not upset me
that makes me so sad for the QA and programmers of the game that did a fucking fantastic job

it's not about when the animation starts

I tested with both I-NO's wake up super and the training mode mission.

It just expects you to do the input way faster. It's not about when the buffer starts.

The input doesn't need to happen during the get up animation, it has to happen a WAYS into the animation. You need to have really fast thumbs.

@killmikaself Most modern fighting games are full to the brim with systems - Smash has way fewer than most, and you can usually explain them in one sentence. Add that to not having to keep track of super meters for most characters, and Smash is definitely the most beginner friendly.

@killmikaself Also, one last thing - combos are de-emphasized in Smash because of a system called DI. There are plenty of real combos in the game but also plenty of things mid level players will do where all you have to do is hold away from the opponent and they will miss the next attack.

@killmikaself If you can listen to advice and implement it you will immediately jump up in skill level even with just a little bit of practice. The game has skill level based matchmaking so there's no harm in letting your GSP drop until you're fighting people at your level.

@killmikaself Again, assuming you weren't serious about the "all Smash players are pedophiles" talk, find someone who is willing to play easy on you and give you advice. So much of people's lack of skill in smash can be fixed not with practice, but simply with knowing when to use what moves.

@killmikaself The biggest factor of this is every character having the same inputs and combos being fairly unimportant until you really start trying to master a specific character. Smash relies on combos much less than most other fighting games.

@killmikaself However, if you pick up a character and try to learn them, and you have good fundamentals, it really won't take long to start playing them fairly well. Like, you can get a new character up to low mid level in an hour with good fundimentals.

@killmikaself I can't promise that you can easily just learn random with no experience, it will take some practice (some characters have really weird up Bs so first step is definitely learning how to use them - I'm still bad at recovering with Ness or Lucas).

@killmikaself For instance, if you're playing a sword character, you can universally count on forward air attacking in front of you with the sword, or forward tilt attacking in front of you with the sword. These rules are so rarely broken that again, you only need to remember the exceptions.

@killmikaself Most of this "memorization" is going to come from experience, not like studying for a test, but most normal A moves are so rare on having any strange properties that you don't even have to remember anything about them.

@killmikaself Tilts are almost always faster than smash attacks so they're almost always the best thing to use in "neutral" (the stage where both fighters are on even ground and can shield). Some characters have tether grabs (long range, slow grabs) so you just have to remember which are those

@killmikaself and you only need to remember the exception to those rules. For instance, with a few exceptions, nair is a "get off me" move and is most character's best option out of shield. Back air is usually a high knockback move. For many character's Up B is a good option out of shield.

@killmikaself And when it comes to that, you can memorize the B moves and be good usually. If you do an attack in a direction with A, you can be assured that your character is going to attack in that direction. From there, there are a few "rules" that most characters follow...

@killmikaself You can get up to mid levels while only learning very basic combos, or even no combos at all. But that's not the only thing. Every character has the same inputs for attacks, meaning you don't have to memorize what they are, only what they do.

@killmikaself Smash Ultimate has more characters than any other fighting game I can think of and yet it's the only fighting game I would ever consider playing random in. This is for several reasons. One is that Smash Ultimate has a VERY low requirement of using combos.

@killmikaself The movement in Smash Bros is very free and the closest thing to a 2D platformer of any fighting game, whereas most fighting games have locked in jump arcs and don't feel like free movement until you get fairly good at them (for some games you have things like air dashing).

@killmikaself I wanted to give another response to this just in the case of Smash Bros - assuming "all Smash Bros players are pedophiles" was said in the heat of emotion and not really meant, smash is the biggest exception to every complaint about fighting games in the thread (1)

Adding tessellation makes a convincing PS1 style popping and warping that works with high FOVs as well! https://t.co/3f2kVyxGjl
@NewBlood I'm curious, is this the same method you used?

float exp = pow(1.5, output.positionCS.w);
output.positionCS /= (exp * output.positionCS.w / (exp - 1));

After screwing around I recreated the polygon warping as it exists in Ultrakill. Not completely accurate but doesn't require a geometry shader and works great with high FOVs. Posting the formula in the replies https://t.co/9lG4bEBfT5
Same shader, but no tessellation or near clip plane clipping of polygons: https://t.co/9Xxwyq77Wc

Some indie games simply take the clip space position and divide them by the absolute value of their W component. This will create a good warping effect mostly, but as vertices get close to the camera the textures will stretch off to infinity. Clipping on near plane is needed.

Clipping polygons on the near clip plane as well as tessellating polygons with verts where z<2 to create the "popping" effect and make sure that the warping does not get too out of control (as it otherwise would as points approach Z=0 in clip space). Done with a geometry shader. https://t.co/dscmR3zlsu

Sequence breaking is a big part of the metroidvania experience, since the start of the genre. Unfortunately, most metroidvanias don't enable it. Ori is the first game in a long time that does, and it's one of its strengths. PLEASE don't take that away.

@OriTheGame I'm getting a ton of mileage and having a lot of fun sequence breaking Ori and the Will of the Wisps; it is possible to softlock in some ways by sequence breaking, and while you should fix the softlocks, PLEASE allow the sequence breaking! It's a ton of fun.

@CoachShinshi @OriTheGame It would be really nice if it was locked during gameplay, but could move offscreen when paused. Being able to move the mouse to my second monitor when paused is really useful as a streamer.

Difficulty is Hard btw

I got top 100 on 4 of the boss time trials in Ori and the Will of the Wisps. I did this in 3 hours. Some of them only took a few successful attempts, including one where I got top 50. Are people not attempting these or do they not understand the concept of min-maxing?
@SkyOverVoid1 @HelelLucerna @OriTheGame I didn't play the first game so I don't know.

@SkyOverVoid1 @HelelLucerna @OriTheGame Remember to optimize earlier segments. You get a "breather" easy segment halfway through the sequence but aside from that, the further ahead of the worm you get, the easier it becomes. The rubber band AI is there but it's not overwhelming.

@SkyOverVoid1 @HelelLucerna @OriTheGame Also, remember that if you dash off a platform or directly off a wall without jumping first, you can dash again. Other than that it's mostly just trial and error and memorizing what's coming up. Once you know what to do in every section it's not really that bad.

@SkyOverVoid1 @HelelLucerna @OriTheGame Good luck. Probably one of the hardest segments of the game. Should be a lot less bad if you unequip sticky walls (the most major controls problem in the sequence is caused by being unable to dash through sand while sticking to it). Would recommend getting triple jump.

@SkyOverVoid1 @HelelLucerna @OriTheGame The speed of escape sequences scales based on difficulty. If you're on normal, it will probably be fine. If you're on hard, prepare for pain and frustration. I recommend taking off your "stick to walls" spirit shard as it hurts more than it helps in that segment.

and rebind that control first. The whole experience was so bafflingly awful that all of it combined convinced me to refund the game before I'd even started playing.

Instead what the menu did was simply not allow me to bind the control at all, forcing me to play a game of cup stacking with my god damn control binding menu, figuring out what buttons everything is bound to (where it's all stuff like "button 10" or "button 3")... (cont)

I also want to mention the main controller rebinding menu was EXTREMELY frustrating. Standard procedure when you try to bind to a button that's already selected is to blank out the other control that is binded to that button, or swap with that control.

Then when I tried to do the same for a different control, it took the button that was in that slot and moved it into the previous blank slot, making that new slot blank. Very bizarre behavior for a control rebinding menu.

@NIGORO in case you want to try to reproduce the bug, it was on the "remap system controls" screen, for gamepad, PS4 controller. When I pressed confirm, instead of allowing me to choose a control to rebind to, it instead made it completely blank.

@UnaliveSDA If you do it when there isn't a cliff you'll see why. Just a quirk in how the game handles the momentum change that results in a higher velocity magnitude during a very small portion of the cap throw.

@UnaliveSDA You basically have to do something we call the "Gurt Cancel" where you do a ground pound boost at an angle and then, with proper timing, press B and Y at the same time to roll cancel and throw your cap at around a 90 degree angle sideways.

@UnaliveSDA You can also get to Memorial Park in Metro Kingdom without the power line and without glitches. The glydon skip in Lost Kingdom is the harder of the two, there's some serious momentum fuckery required, here's a link: https://t.co/AcuhGS9jN1
